revised_title: The Evolution of Membership Criteria in the Royal Society
tldr: This article explores the historical development of membership criteria in the Royal Society, focusing on how the requirement of explicit qualifications for candidates evolved over time. The author discusses the initial acceptance of members with minimal scientific knowledge and the introduction of the 1730 statute, which aimed to raise standards and ensure that the majority of members were men of science. The article also highlights the value of certificates for candidates as a source of social and intellectual history, providing insights into the values and expectations of the time.
